columns.text: In this exercise, we are asked to answer the following questions applying the concept of exchange rate risk.

**Exchange rate** is the value of a country's currency when expressed in *another country's currency*.  An **exchange rate risk** is a risk occurring in international operations where the *currency values varies*.

We will look at Figure 21.1 of this book to answer the questions in the exercise.

The company is importing computer motherboards in Singapore. The exchange rate, as shown in Figure 21.1, are as follows:

<center>

| |in US$ |per US$ |
|--|:--:|:--:| 
|Singapore Dollar |0..7982 | 1.2528 |

## a. 

First, we will calculate the profit if the exchange rate goes up by 10 percent over the next 90 days. We will multiply the current exchange rate per U.S. and  the increase of 1.10.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Increased Exchange Rate} &= \text{Current Exchange Rate}\times{\text{Growth Rate}}\\
&= \text{S\$ 1.2528}\times{\text{1.10}}\\
&=\boxed{\text{S\$ 1.3781}}\\
\end{aligned}$$
 
The exchange rate if it goes up by 10% is **S$ 1.3781** per U.S. dollar.

Now that we have determined the cost of production in U.S. dollars, we can now determine the profit. 

$$\begin {array}{lrr}
\text{Sales Price}&&\$~~~~~~~~~185~\\
\text{Cost of Production}&&\underline{(158.55)}\\
\text{Profit per Unit}&&\$~~~~~~~26.45\\
\text{Multiply by: Units to be sold}&&\underline{~~30,000}\\
\text{Profit}&&\underline{\underline{\$~~ 793,500}}\\
\end{array}$$
 
The profit if the exchange rate goes up by 10 percent over the next 90 days is **$793,500**.

## b.

Next, we will calculate the profit if the exchange rate goes down by 10 percent over the next 90 days. We will multiply the current exchange rate per U.S. and  the decrease of 0.90.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Increased Exchange Rate} &= \text{Current Exchange Rate}\times{\text{Decreased Rate}}\\
&= \text{S\$ 1.2528}\times{\text{0.90}}\\
&=\boxed{\text{S\$ 1.1275}}\\
\end{aligned}$$
 
The exchange rate if it goes down by 10% is **S$ 1.1275** per U.S. dollar.

Now that we have determined the cost of production in U.S. dollars, we can now determine the profit. 

$$\begin {array}{lrr}
\text{Sales Price}&&\$~~~~~~~~~~~185~\\
\text{Cost of Production}&&\underline{(193.79)}\\
\text{Profit per Unit}&&\$~~~~~~~~(8.79)\\
\text{Multiply by: Units to be sold}&&\underline{~~30,000}\\
\text{Profit}&&\underline{\underline{\$~ (263,700)}}\\
\end{array}$$
 
The profit if the exchange rate goes down by 10 percent over the next 90 days is **($263,700)**.

## d.

Lastly, we are asked to determine the percentage rise or fall represent in terms of the Singapore dollar versus the U.S. dollar.

As a conclusion, the profit if the exchange rate goes up by 10 percent over the next 90 days is **\$793,500** while the profit if the exchange rate goes down by 10 percent over the next 90 days is **(\$263,700)**.  
\
The break-even exchange rate is **S$ 1.1811 per $1** and the **percentage fall by 5.72%** in terms of the Singapore dollar versus the U.S. dollar.
